column2: Heavy rainfall during the spring is good for growing crops, but the mud can hinder travel.
Heavy rainfall during summer or autumn is bad for crops which are ripening or ready to be harvested.
Stormy weather damages crops and wreaks havoc on livestock.
Droughts are very bad for crops, livestock, and any people in the afflicted region.
Rats have gotten into food stores all across [This.GetName].
Heavy rainfall causes rivers to overflow their banks and flood nearby lands, destroying crops, threatening livestock, and driving people from their homes.
Wind and rain along coastlines leads to higher than normal swells which inundate low-lying areas and wreak havoc on shipping.
Wind in the desert can create massive sandstorms which severely restrict travel.
Rain in the desert is rare but extremely welcome and usually accompanied by a great flowering.
Storms in the desert batter unprotected inhabitants with wind and rain, potentially causing flash floods and poor traveling conditions.
Heavy snow in winter disrupts all the necessary patterns of life.
The combination of storms and snow can make travel a nightmare and strand people indoors until conditions clear.
A warmer than usual winter eases the usual deprivations of the coldest season.
A particularly cold winter brings starvation and death to everyone caught in its grasp.
A warmer spring is good for planting and means plentiful food for livestock.
When winter lasts into spring the usual pattern of agriculture is disrupted and food supplies are strained for everyone.
Brutally hot summers are bad for people and livestock alike.
Cooler than usual summers are good for everyone.
Cloudy weather during the summer is bad for ripening crops.
Bright and sunny weather during the summer is excellent for ripening crops.
A warmer than usual autumn is good for everyone.
An early arrival of winter brings all the potential suffering of cold weather, but can also destroy ripened crops before they can be harvested.
